wikitext.*:
{{Expansion}}

Several locations have been given names after fictional locations and characters of [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]]'s [[Middle-earth]] and wider [[Legendarium]].

== Cities==
===Geldrop ===
[[Geldrop]] is a Dutch town with a neighbourhood whose streets are all related to Tolkien and his Legendarium.<ref>{{webcite|author=Frank Jacobs|articleurl=https://bigthink.com/strange-maps/has-middle-earth-joined-the-eurozone/|articlename=Suburb Designs Its Neighborhood around J.R.R. Tolkien’s Middle-Earth|dated=13 February 2016|website=BigThing.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
===Jacksonville===
[[Jacksonville]] is a city in Florida that has a neighbourhood with street names based on [[The Lord of the Rings]] and [[The Hobbit]].<ref>{{webcite|author=Ennis Davis|articleurl=https://www.thejaxsonmag.com/article/10-jax-neighborhoods-with-thematic-street-names-page-2/|articlename=10 Jax neighborhoods with thematic street names|dated=5 December 2016|website=TheJaxsonMag.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
== Geographical features==
=== Mountains===
*Mount [[Shadowfax]].<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://apps.gov.bc.ca/pub/bcgnws/names/58360.html|articlename=Mount Shadowfax|dated=|website=www2.gov.bc.ca/|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*Mount [[Gandalf]].<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://apps.gov.bc.ca/pub/bcgnws/names/58340.html|articlename=Mount Gandalf|dated=|website=www2.gov.bc.ca/|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*Mount [[Aragorn]].<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://apps.gov.bc.ca/pub/bcgnws/names/9159.html|articlename=Mount Aragorn|dated=|website=www2.gov.bc.ca/|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
===Seamounts ===
*[[Eriador]] Seamount.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4216|articlename=Eriador Seamount|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Rohan]] Seamount.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4964|articlename=Rohan Seamount|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Gondor]] Seamount.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4965|articlename=Gondor Seamount|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Eye of Sauron]] Seamount.<ref name=EOS>{{webcite|author=Harry Baker|articleurl=https://www.livescience.com/eye-of-sauron-deep-sea-volcano.html|articlename= Eye of Sauron' volcano and other deep-sea structures discovered in underwater 'Mordor |dated=23 July 2023|website=livescience.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Barad-dûr]] Seamount.<ref name=EOS/>
*[[Ered Lithui]] Seamount.<ref name=EOS/>
*[[Fangorn Forest|Fangorn]] Bank.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4963|articlename=Fangorn Bank|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Edoras]] Bank.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4217|articlename=Edoras Bank|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[Isengard]] Ridge.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4962|articlename=Isengard Ridge|dated=|website=MarineRegions.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
==Astronomy==
===Titan===
[[Titan]] is one of [[Wikipedia:Saturn|Saturn]]'s moons. Its mountains (''Montes'') are named after mountains in [[Arda]] and hills (''colles'') after characters.<ref>{{webcite|author=Gabrielle Barone|articleurl=https://airandspace.si.edu/stories/editorial/unexpected-journey-tolkien-titan|articlename=The Unexpected Journey from Tolkien to Titan|dated=|website=|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>

The named ''montes'' of Titan are: [[Mountains of Angmar|Angmar Montes]], [[Dolmed|Dolmed Montes]], [[Mount Doom|Doom Mons]], [[Echoriad|Echoriat Montes]], [[Erebor|Erebor Mons]], [[Mount Gram|Gram Montes]], [[Irensaga|Irensaga Montes]], [[Merlock Mountains|Merlock Montes]], [[Mindolluin|Mindolluin Montes]], [[Misty Mountains|Misty Montes]], [[Mountains of Mithrim|Mithrim Montes]], [[Rerir|Rerir Montes]], [[Taniquetil|Taniquetil Montes]].
===Asteroids===
*2991 [[Bilbo]].<ref>{{webcite|author=IAU Minor Planet Center|articleurl=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?utf8=%E2%9C%93&object_id=2991|articlename=(2991) Bilbo = 1975 JC = 1979 SY3 = 1982 HV = 1982 KB2|dated=3 August 2018|website=MinorPlanetCenter.net|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*2675 Tolkien.<ref>Schmadel, Lutz D. (2007). "(2675) Tolkien". Dictionary of Minor Planet Names – (2675) Tolkien. Springer Berlin Heidelberg. p. 219. ISBN 978-3-540-00238-3.</ref>
*378214 [[Sauron]].<ref>{{webcite|author=IAU Minor Planet Center|articleurl=https://minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=378214|articlename=(378214) Sauron = 2007 AP11|dated=|website=MinorPlanetCenter.net|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
===Other===
*Kuiper Belt object 385446 [[Manwë]] and its moon [[Thorondor]].<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://academic-accelerator.com/encyclopedia/385446-manwe|articlename=385446 Manwe|dated=|website=|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*Trans-Neptunian object 174567 [[Varda]] and its moon [[Ilmarë]].<ref>{{webcite|author=IAU Minor Planet Center|articleurl=https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=174567|articlename=(174567) Varda = 2003 MW12|dated=|website=MinorPlanetCenter.net|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*A series of regions of Pluto called [[Balrog]] Macula.<ref>{{webcite|author=Adam Rogers|articleurl=https://www.wired.com/2015/07/new-nerdy-mythology-plutos-place-names/|articlename=The New, Nerdy Mythology of Pluto's Place Names|dated=|website=Wired.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*The Eye of Sauron is a nickname given to many objects due to a similar appearance including, the nebulae M 1-42,<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://tgdaily.com/science/space/69866-the-eye-of-sauron-is-nebula-eso-456-67/|articlename=The Eye Of Sauron Is Nebula ESO 456-67|dated=|website=tgdaily.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref> Helix Nebula,<ref>{{webcite|author=Paulo Lobao|articleurl=https://skyandtelescope.org/online-gallery/the-eye-of-sauron-aka-ngc7293/|articlename=The Eye of Sauron (AKA NGC7293)|dated=|website=SkyandTelescope.org|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref> star system HR 4796A,<ref>{{webcite|author=Flora Graham|articleurl=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn25676-eye-of-sauron-star-spotted-by-planet-hunting-camera/|articlename=Eye of Sauron star spotted by planet-hunting camera|dated=|website=NewScientist.com|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref> and Seyfert galaxy NGC 4151.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2011/n4151/|articlename=NGC 4151: An Active Black Hole in the "Eye of Sauron"|dated=|website=chandra.Harvard.edu|accessed=4 February 2024}}</ref>
*[[wikipedia:WHL0137-LS|Earendel]], a star in the constellation of [[wikipedia:Cetus|Cetus]]. Even though it is an Anglo-Saxon name that predates Tolkien, the researches involved in its discovery were fans of his works and chose the name for that reason.<ref>[https://www.space.com/hubble-most-distant-star-tolkien-name-earendil Meet Earendel: Hubble telescope's most distant star discovery gets a Tolkien-inspired name], space.com (accessed 6 February 2024)</ref><ref group=note>[[Wiktionary:Earendel|Earendel]] is an [[Old English]] name referring to the morning star. It was borrowed verbatim by Tolkien for his earliest legendarium (''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'') but envisioned as [[Qenya]]; it changed to ''Earendil'' in the mid-1940s.</ref>
